segments.text: The following is an interview by Laney Holder of Miss Irene Taylor, her great-great-aunt, a resident of Park Plaza Nursing Home in Mark, Texas.
Miss Taylor is 84 and a retired schoolteacher.
The date is February 15, 1975.
OK.
In the year of 1864, the Great Civil War
Why and what was it all about?
It concerned the freedom of the Negro slaves.
Our grandparents, the McCullochs, are you getting it all right?
The McCullochs and the Caldwells had never owned a slave, but they became involved.
by letting the good Presbyterian preacher tell them they should vote to free the slaves.
He only won.
I got to say this.
Our grandparents, McCullochson, had never a slave, but they became involved by letting the good Presbyterian preacher tell them they should.
He owned one nigger slave.
How did he come by that nigger slave?
Well, I don't know.
That we don't know.
He only had one slave?
He only had one slave, but he told all this congregation how to vote.
He had a slave, but he wanted them to not vote?
That's right.
And so they did what he told them.
Of course, he told them, I guess he got it from the religious
points you knew that it wasn't right to keep a person in slavery.
I've never heard all of them, but they voted as he suggested.
And that caused them to lose their homes on the good farm lands of mid-Tennessee.
They were living among people who
had voted to hold the Negro in slavery, and in so many words, they became outcasts in their own land.
They became outcasts because they voted against... Because they voted for... To free them?
To free the Negro.
The neighbors ran them out?
What is it?
Did their neighbors run them out?
Yes, their neighbors all voted to hold them because they had slaves, you see.
But these people of ours had no slaves.
They were just letting folks that had their slaves tell them what to do.
They didn't have them, they didn't know what to do.
had voted for the Negro slavery war, they became outcasts in their land.
They lingered about trying to make
They lingered about for two years trying to start over and thinking maybe things would improve on them.
Did they stay there?
Yeah, they stayed around there two years and they were scared to death.
They wouldn't have stopped at anything.
committed murder or anything else, those neighbors were, that were mad at them for voting to get free their neighbors.
Well, were the neighbors freed then?
Well, they had not known.
They were still as slaves.
They were not freed until later.
In other words, they were people without a life.
So they decided to leave and go in search of a new home in the wilds of the west of Texas.
With the first buds of spring, they loaded
the wagons, six or eight wagons in all.
I don't know just how many, but several wagons.
They were the McCullochs and the Caldwells.
They were the kin people, and then there were some others that went, too.
And of course, our grandparents had three children.
Four.
They had four, really.
Three girls and a boy.
Mama was the youngest of the girls.
And this boy was a little older than she was.
And he was the one.
Well, I'll go on.
Just kind of stay with Mama.
And so they decided to leave.
Because...
towards the wilds of Texas.
They were headed for the wilds of Texas, the first buds of spring.
I read that one.
And look, they loaded the wagons, six or eight in number, and for safety's sake, pledged to start cooking.
You want to wait a few minutes?
I don't know who went beside their relatives, but there was a group that went, I'm sure, because there wasn't such a big family of the McCullers or such a big family of the Caldwells.
They were relatives?
Yes.
Our grandmother McCulloch had been a Caldwell, and these others were her relatives.
And so they went on and started banning the stream and it took them until, and of course the roads were about over.
But they got to, well I don't know exactly what month, but it was sometime in the summer.
How in the world did they decide to come to West Texas, of all places?
places to come clear to Texas, and where they came to.
They came to, well, at that time, you see, there was no towns in Texas.
The nearest one to Texas was Jefferson, Texas.
There's a Jefferson there now.
But that wasn't the town they came to, I suppose.
The little place where they came to, that's where Papa and Mama were married.
I didn't think I'd ask this question.
And all of Starksville.
And I don't know where this here is.
Starksville?
Starksville.
Not Clarksville, but Starksville.
And I don't know whether there's a settlement there now or not.
I don't think there is.
But now that's where they settled.
And when they went to town to buy groceries, they had to go to Jefferson, which was a long trip away from where I was.
St. Louis, Texas?
Jefferson is in deep East Texas now.
Now, there's still a Jefferson there.
There's a town there.
Someday maybe you can go to Jefferson.
And they would have to go by wagon, of course, and then lay in their supplies with, you know, for several months at a time.
Should buy flour by the barrel, sugar.
I wonder what the prices were like then.
I don't know.
I don't know about that.
Claire might know.
I'll ask him.
There's a man in there with him, but I don't know.
Some history or something you might be able to find out.
The prices?
The price of the flour and the sugar.
I was just wondering if you might... And the bacon.
Now they got bacon, I'm sure, somewhere.
Of course they raided as soon as they could.
I don't guess they took any cows with them.
And somebody mentioned they took the cows to make them some milk for women and children.
But there were very few children in that group.
My mommy was the youngest, and I think she was 12 or 14 years old.
And there just weren't many children in that group at all.
And so, but anyway, I understand that they took the cows and cows.
And I don't guess they tried to take a pill with that on the mansion.
They did.
Well, did they homestead the land or buy it or what?
Well, now I don't know.
I'll ask Claire.
They bought that man, and he knows who he bought it from.
He bought the man, the son of the man they bought it from, lived in Rosebeck, and there's still some people there by that name now.
Hayes.
H-A-Y-S-E, I guess.
Well, and that's who they bought it from.
He said that they bought it, and I don't know the price now.
I just don't know.
I can go back and ask him if he knows anything about the price.
I don't imagine he does.
And they couldn't have had much money to bring with them because they didn't get anything for what they were buying.
And way later on, there was a man that said she was going to stay.
She went home, went home, and she stayed alone.
That's where they were.
And they couldn't bring her out.
Don't know whether she died there or what became of her.
Mama called her Aunt Jane.
I had nothing.
But anyway, she left behind some.
They're all good.
Of course, it wasn't much, but it was a whole lot.
Some money later on was called for the mountain land.
That's where she had lived.
And they, a whole, and I remember when my mom or I, I guess I remember, I've heard it talked about though.
Many of them, they got some money.
And it was put in that little farm at Thornton, it's called.
Well, how did they get from West Texas to here?
Why did they come here?
Why did they finally leave?
Oh, well, you see, it's a long story about where they lived.
They lived, I don't know how long they lived.
And then they moved from Starksville to what was called Lamar County.
They moved from there and not so far from the Blossom.
Now there's a town in Blossom Hill.
That's where a lot of- Is that in South Texas?
No, it's in North Texas.
North Central Texas.
And that's where they went when they left that little place on the border where they stopped.
And they came there and that's where they
You know, they had their land there, and they had a good farm and made such a terrible, sad mistake when they left their farm in Lamar County and went west.
Why didn't they make just more opportunity?
That's what they thought.
They were looking for opportunity, I suppose.
And still these band of relatives that came were all still together.
And this, and you see, Clem and I are the only ones that are left.
And our mother's left.
How many children were in your family?
In this valley, Mama had three sisters.
That's right, she had had three sisters.
And she only had
two sisters, because one had died back in, the oldest child was a girl, and it had died back in Tennessee with whooping cough.
Somebody told them if they would, she was about 12 years old, if they would rub her chest with the preparation of tallow and something else, and the first turpentine of what, she would never cough.
And they did.
And whatever it was.
And she didn't come.
But at the end of the time, instead of getting rid of her, six weeks getting rid of her and go off like an ordinary child, she died.
Because that stoppage of that flea in her throat caused her... That turpentine and talon?
Talon and turpentine, I think.
I know it was talon.
That he's rubbing on?
They rubbed it on her chest, made a mixture of it.
and rubbed it on her chest.
And that band was not in there anymore.
I had two sisters, and she, that was three, and the brother was just older than my mom.
My mom was the youngest of the mom.
Esther, E-S-T-H-E-R. And the way she, her, our father had come from Tennessee,
two but not the same place in Tennessee.
And he had a relative named Taylor, her only relative that we know of, Taylor, who was Porter McCullough.
And our daddy, and maybe I guess our uncle Sam, that's the one that your granddad Taylor was named for, had made
And I don't know what year they married, and I would have to look that up.
It's in the Bible, they told me.
But we haven't got that here, but you have everything.
How long do you have to work on this?
Oh, a long time.
I'll be back down here.
And we have the...
Yes, we have the Bible.
And we also have the Lamb.
The first in the Bible.
The Bible is there too.
It was on the table.
Your parents' Bible?
Yes.
And the table and the Lamb.
We do not have the chariot.
Now we have a handmade chair, but I don't think it's the chair that went with the table.
But we use it all the time anyway, because it's oak.
And then they were married.
At that time they had a home of their own.
They would all go together.
And there's one thing about it that I never heard.
There was never a death on the way, which was unusual for that day and time.
None of them died on the way here?
No.
Let me interrupt you just a second.
That was unusual for back... How long did it take them?
Well, it just says...
They got here in the summer.
They left in early spring.
Several months, you know.
Well, this is kind of backtracking, but didn't they all originally come from Scotland?
Yes, yes, they did, of course.
Now, they had the ancestors had come from Scotland.
But that's, now I don't know much about that.
Don't you have the money box that
Don't you have the money box that they...
Yes, we have the box that... Now that man that... Well, that money...
He was a...
This couple were rather old, but they had a son.
And they were frail.
They were very frail.
But he wanted to come to the United States to live.
He felt like there was more future in the United States for him than there was back in that part of Scotland, I don't know.
So they sold everything they had and put it in gold in that money box.

boarded ship and started to of course it was a sailboat and both both parents died on the way they can recall something a mouth disease i suppose it was called black tongue and they both died and were buried soon they bring their children with them
Well, no, they didn't have any.
This son was the only thing, and he had never been married.
Just they and their son, parents, McCulloch, and their son were the ones that came.
And so they all came, but he came on.
And he landed in America in about 1720.
And he invested that money, all he had in the world, and it turned out to be worthless stock.
He lost everything?
He lost everything.
I said, now, what his name was, I don't know.
It may be in some of the books at home.
I don't know what his name was.
But he went on and raised a family from then on out.
That's what they're all.
And then they drifted.
He drifted directly on down to where Mama and them were living in Tennessee.
Our grandfather was named Porter.
Our grandfather is not the man that lost the gold.
I know that.
And our cousin, this Rufus Taylor, the only Taylor relative Mama ever saw, went back to Tennessee.
The father's sister?
Well, no.
He was our father's first cousin.
First cousin.
And he went back to Tennessee.
And he wasn't, to say, involved in this.
He was in a different part.
He was not involved in the Civil War.
Well, did any of your family serve in the Civil War?
Do you know?
Did which?
Any of your family serve in the Civil War?
Yes.
Yes, they did.
But now I don't know.
Grandfather had a brother killed in the Civil War.
He was either killed or died.
I don't know just how many.
I'll ask Clem.
He might remember.
He was trying to get some horses out somewhere, and he was drowned.
It was during the Civil War, all right.
He was a soldier, but he was drowned, Clem says.
Instead of murdered, he was drowned.
Okay.
Going back to when the family was in Blossom, where did they move after that?
Where did they leave?
Where did they go to when they left Blossom?
Well, now that's where they went to West Texas.
And that was, they went to Merkle.
It's near Abilene, isn't it?
It's near Abilene.
That's where they went from there.
And Clem was
Now, Clem was born at Blossom.
Where was Anpot born?
Well, I guess he was born there, too.
They were there a number of years.
Were they farming or ranching?
No, they were farming.
As dry as it is?
Well, it wasn't as dry at Blossom as it was.
Now, they got into the drought when they got west, you know, when they went west.
They had plenty of rain at Blossom.
It was plenty of rain.
And they were, I guess, clean.
And then you see there was Dorothy.
She was born.
She's the oldest.
She's the oldest.
And the next is Bill's daddy, our...
That was Belle.
And then there was a boy.
There was a boy named Porter that died.
He was next to Belle, I think.
And then next was your granddaddy.
And then there was Albert, the one that lived in Dallas.
And then last of all was Claire.
And they were all born in Lamar County.
Are you the youngest?
I'm the last.
And Uncle Roy was next to you?
Yeah, he was just over there.
And we were born in West Texas.
We were born near Abilene in Morocco.
And of these Carl Wells, I can go back to them because they were the near relatives.
Now, they had a daughter, Carl Wells did, and she married a man named
Hudson.
And she was just mama's age.
And she married this man named Hudson.
They were living in, or still living in Lamar County when they married.
And they had one child, a girl.
And that girl, that made her just about Clem's age, 87.
And she lived until Christmas.
She was about 87 and she lived in Fort Worth.
We heard from her as long as she was able to write.
And she died just before Christmas.
We heard from her, but we don't know the day she was buried and all, but we know.
Now that was the only one of the Carwell.
There was a bigger group in Mama's family than there was in
in the Colorado.
Your mother was McCulloch?
McCulloch, M-C-C-O-W-L-O-C-H. Why did they leave Merkle?
Why did they leave Merkle?
Well, it was dry and somebody told them
Miss Clem said that Mama and Papa always depended on this Uncle Sam that your daddy was named for.
He was a mighty fine man, but he wasn't any better manager than the rest of them.
But Papa always depended on him a lot.
So they listened to what he said?
Yeah, they listened to what he said.
And he said they ought to go to South Texas.
That's when they went to South Texas.
And so a little town is there now.
See, we didn't leave there.
We didn't leave South Texas until after the 1900 storm.
That's the Galveston storm?
Not Galveston.
Big storm in the 1900s.
